review: In all fairness, it's only been maybe 1/2 hour. But everything I've tried so far has been seamless. I haven't tried Netflix or other apps, but i have two other devices that can stream Netflix (TV and Blu-ray), so I'm not worried about that if it doesn't work well. Of course it would be nice if it streamed Amazon, but my two other aforementioned devices do that, too, so this was not a dealbreaker. One hint though, if you have a Mac, the remote will try to operate your computer, too. That was annoying until I figured out how to turn it off (System Preferences > Security & Privacy > General > Advanced > click Disable remote control infrared receiver). I don't use a remote with a Mac, but I can imagine that if you do, it may annoy you to have to turn this off completely rather than pairing with a specific remote. There may be a workaround for this, not sure.One thing I really like is that I have two options, I can access what's on my computer or iCloud directly from AppleTV (and use the apps), or I can mirror my computer if I want to stream something that's not an AppleTV app, such as Spotify, through AirPlay (this works with Amazon video, too, but you may need to turn off the AppleTV screensaver), though that does require a few extra steps. I originally bought a Roku 3 but found its lack of flexibility annoying and ended up selling it after one week on eBay (besides that, the Netflix interface on Roku was awful compared with my Panasonic Blu-ray). The AppleTV is about 95% what I was looking for. Now, if someone could just replace my Hopper, receiver and Blu-ray with something this petite! BTW,  I have a MacBook Pro running Mavericks. I don't know if AirPlay works with a PC.And P.S., if anyone is wondering why you might want to send something like Spotify to your TV, my TV audio plays through my stereo system, not through the TV speakers. I used to have to plug my computer (or iPod or iPhone) into the stereo receiver through a <gasp> cable.
